reasoning: The critique targets the post’s “implausibly low max speed” move (counterargument #6), alleging it relies on intuition that already presumes high labor–compute substitutability. This is fairly central insofar as #6 is one of the more important listed reasons to distrust negative-ρ estimates, but the overall position also leans on several other independent considerations (#5, #7, #2, #3), so refuting #6 would weaken rather than collapse the case. The circularity objection has moderate strength: the post does use intuitive scenarios to reject low implied ceilings, and without independent evidence this can look question-begging; however, it’s not purely circular because those scenarios could in principle be supported by historical trends, concrete engineering constraints, or expert-elicited effect sizes (even if the post doesn’t fully cash that out), so the critique doesn’t fully undercut the claim. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little dead weight; correctness is fairly high but slightly overstated in implying the max-speed intuition has no independent content beyond the disputed conclusion.
title: Rejecting speed ceilings via high-substitutability scenarios assumes the conclusion
